The Voting Accessibility for the Elderly and Handicapped Act is amended to ensure that no individual can be denied the right to vote in a Federal election based on disability and that every voter has the right to vote independently. The accessibility of polling places is also addressed by amending the responsibilities of the chief election officer of the State. The Voting Accessibility for the Elderly and Handicapped Act is amended to ensure that all polling methods for Federal elections are accessible to disabled and elderly voters, including providing ballots in various accessible media, large type instructions at polling places, printed information in accessible formats, and ensuring all methods enable accessibility. The Voting Accessibility for the Elderly and Handicapped Act is amended to ensure registration facilities and services are accessible, including registration information in accessible media and procedures for eligible voters to register easily. The Voting Accessibility for the Elderly and Handicapped Act is amended to increase fines for violations, with a maximum of $5,000 for the first violation and $10,000 for subsequent violations. Additionally, the relationship with other laws is clarified in the amendments. The Voting Accessibility for the Elderly and Handicapped Act is amended to increase fines for violations, with a maximum of $5,000 for the first violation and $10,000 for subsequent violations. The amendments also clarify the relationship with other laws and ensure that state laws providing equal or greater access for disabled and elderly voters are not invalidated or limited. Definitions in the Act are updated, including the definition of the "Access Board" as the Architectural and Transportation Barriers Compliance Board. The Voting Accessibility for the Elderly and Handicapped Act is amended to update definitions, including the definition of "chief election officer" and "independently." References to "handicapped" are changed to "disabled" in the Act. The Voting Accessibility for the Elderly and Handicapped Act is amended to change references from "handicapped" to "disabled" in all related laws and documents. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to the Rehabilitation Act of 1973. The Attorney General must create regulations within a year of this Act's enactment, consistent with Access Board guidelines. The Access Board will issue guidelines within nine months. The term "Access Board" refers to the Architectural and Transportation Barriers Compliance Board. A transition plan is required. The chief election officer of each State must develop a transition plan within 3 months of regulations being promulgated to ensure polling places comply with the Voting Accessibility for the Elderly and Handicapped Act. The plan must be developed in coordination with local election officials and individuals with disabilities, include specific recommendations for compliance, and be made available to the public. The transition plan developed by the chief election officer must comply with the Voting Accessibility for the Elderly and Handicapped Act and be available for public inspection as determined appropriate. The amendments made by this Act will take effect 6 months after regulations are promulgated under section 2(a) or after the first Federal election in the State after December 31, 2000.
